div.p: From Joseph Hooker to Henry Barkly
RBG Kew, Archives, Letters from Joseph Hooker vol 1: ADA-BAR, ff 189-191.

Only extracts relevant to M have been transcribed. […] indicates where text has been omitted by the editors. No. 10
All the letters to Barkly (but not other correspondents) are numbered in this way, and are typescript in purple ink, or possibly carbon copies, in several cases with annotations or corrections not in Hooker's hand. The 'signature' is also typed. None of the letters is marked 'copy', and they may include errors of transcription and/or omissions.

I was very glad to receive yours of the 15th February
sic. Almost certainly H. Barkly to J. Hooker, 13 February 1872 (RBG Kew, Directors' letters vol 189. South African Letters A-G, 1865-1900, f. 175) which encloses an extract of M to H. Barkly, 8 October 1871 (in this edition as 71-10-08b). […] You send capital news of the prospects of finishing the Flora Capensis […] As to Sonder, I quite feel for him, and appreciate Mueller's patriotism, but S. is hopelessly dilatory and very inefficient. Harvey only endured him because he had certain otherwise inaccessible collections […] Poor Mueller is distracted between the pleasures of his new title and pains of his position.
An asterisk in red ink is in the left margin at this point. As far as what he calls persecution is concerned, he is no worse off than I am under Ayrton, in respect of whom I am at open rebellion, having refused obedience and informed Mr. Gladstone of it. I have been up before a Committee of the Cabinet, into whose hands Mr. Gladstone put the whole affair, consisting of Lord Ripon, Lord Halifax and Mr. Cardwell, who are entirely in my favor, as is Mr. Lowe and the Treasury — but it is a case for Mr. G. to act in, he alone can, and he seems to be utterly fascinated by Mr. Ayrton. What will come of it all I cannot conceive. The whole affair has become Club gossip, and I have great difficulty in keeping it from being brought before the House, which would just prevent Mr. G. from doing anything at all. Lord Derby has written for details — Sir J. Lubbock has all the correspondence and will ask the question in the House whenever I say the word. On every account I want to keep the matter quiet. For three months Mr. G. buoyed me up with the assurance that "a plan was under the consideration of the Govt. that would effectually relieve me" — but this all of a sudden broke down, how or why I know not. I believe it was a Bill to have removed Kew from the O. of Works. I then threatened to appeal to the House, and this brough out the Committee of the Cabinet, which has made its report to Mr. G., and there the matter rests. I hope that Lord D. will be prudent, his action is wholly spontaneous.

But I bore you with this — to return to poor Mueller, who takes his sorrows to heart (wh. I do not), I am doing my best to support him, and have assured him that I shall decline the duty the Commissioners threatened to impose on me, of selecting a Superintendent for the Landscape and Gardening department of his Gardens; and shall further remonstrate against such an appointment being made against his wishes. […]
